project.teaser: Solar fuels, produced via solar driven CO2 and water conversion can contribute to drastically reducing GHG emissions and implement a man-made carbon-cycle complementing the natural-one, deploying the circular economy strategy. However, at present, significant improvement in...
project.objective: Solar fuels, produced via solar driven CO2 and water conversion can contribute to drastically reducing GHG emissions and implement a man-made carbon-cycle complementing the natural-one, deploying the circular economy strategy. However, at present, significant improvement in the photocatalysts and reactor technology is required for solar fuels’ production to become technically feasible, scalable, affordable, secure, sustainable, and efficient. DESIRED is a high-risk high-return project, focused on establishing the technological feasibility and sustainability of a novel fuel production system – the DESIRED system – for direct coprocessing of, possibly atmospheric, CO2 and water to produce multi-carbon (C2+) energy-rich products using sunlight as primary energy source. The DESIRED system will produce C2+ solar fuels (without overlooking C1 species such as methanol or methane) by direct coprocessing of CO2 and water using novel and recyclable hybrid photo-electrocatalysts, supported on frustules or zeolites, in an innovative photoreactor design applying, for the first time, oscillatory flow principles, combined with direct light irradiation. With regards to applications, DESIRED will focus on products, which, by 2050, would be used per se or as intermediates to produce drop-in fuels for sectors where direct shift to batteries or H2 is not a technically and cost-efficient option (e.g. aviation). Knowledge of the economic affordability, environmental benefits, and social acceptability of this approach will be investigated. DESIRED promotes an interdisciplinary approach to research and innovation undertaken by a consortium of 7 European partners and complemented by cross-cutting activities including modelling, process simulation, sustainability, and techno-economic assessment as well as impactful dissemination, communication, capacity-building and exploitation activities that support the exchange of knowledge across and beyond the consortium and project.
project.title: Direct co-processing of CO2 and water to sustainable multicarbon energy products in novel photocatalytic reactor ​
project.keywords: catalysis, CO2 conversion, direct light irradiation, frustules, hybrid photoelectron-catalysts, multicarbon products, photoreactor, solar fuels, solar collector, zeolites

webItem.title: Filling the tank
webItem.alternativeText: An illustration of the contributions made by each source to the overall goal of 35 billion cubic metres of biomethane production, rendered as liquid levels in a large cylindrical gas tower.

webItem.title: Fuelling innovation
webItem.alternativeText: An illustration showing how the various elements support biomethane production. Artificial photosynthesis supplies the gas network directly. Wood biomass is gasified and sent to the gas network. Waste waters and organic matter feed the anaerobic digester, which produces biogas that is refined to biomethane before being injected into the gas network. Waste from the city, including CO2, is returned to the anaerobic digester.

webItem.title: Investing in a greener future
webItem.alternativeText: An illustration showing the value of projects in millions of euro, arranged by funding stream. Coordination and Support Actions include Bin2Grid (0.71), BiogasAction (2.0), BIOSURF (1.87), DiBiCoo (3), ISAAC (1.48), ISABEL (1.9) and REGATRACE (3). Research and Innovation Actions include CarbonNeutralLNG (3.31), CRONUS (4.39), DESIRED (3.06), FlexSNG (4.23), NET-Fuels (4.50) and PRODIGIO (2.45). Innovation Actions include BIOMETHAVERSE (9.87), HYFUELUP (10.29), METHAREN (10.36) and SEMPRE-BIO (11.75).

category.title: Projects Information Pack
category.description: Article: Selections of projects in their early stages focusing on a specific research theme

article.teaser: Europe’s energy security is under pressure from rising costs, climate change, domestic and international energy policy, and conflict. Biomethane – natural gas produced from renewable sources such as municipal and agricultural waste – offers a reliable, drop-in fuel that can meet the energy needs of citizens. This Projects Info Pack showcases the research being carried out to grow Europe’s biomethane industry, boosting energy security and helping to deliver on the EU’s ambitions for a competitive, low-carbon economy.

article.title: Innovative biomethane to support Europe’s energy independence
article.teaser: A new Projects Info Pack from CORDIS highlights the ongoing research helping to deliver REPowerEU’s goal of ending reliance on Russian gas imports by 2030 and accelerating Europe’s transition to a clean energy system.

result.title: Scientific & Technical management report I
result.description: Initial report on scientific and technical matters, as addressed in WPs 2, 3, 4 and 5, related to the implementation of the project. It is produced as part of T1.2 and elaborates on the progress, findings and challenges faced by the Work Package Leaders while recommendations are also formulated.

result.title: Requirements traceability matrix for the new-concept, single-tube reactor.

details.authors: Solarska, Renata; Bieńkowski, Krzysztof; Linh, Trinh

result.title: Report on assumptions and scenarios
result.description: In a short document, the main methods for the life cycle sustainability assessment, the set of scenarios, and the scalability assumptions will be defined for further analysis. The deliverable is produced by T5.1.

result.title: Level 1 Single-tube reactor 15mL.
result.description: D3.2 includes the design and P&I drawings of the 15-mL, single-tube reactor, as well as the delivered constructed reactor ready for experimental studies. It is produced by T3.2.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
